General course objectives:
General course objectives
Introduction to theoretical chemical (quantum chemical) methods and their use in modern computational chemistry.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Explain the most important concepts of electronic structure theory
Describe and understand molecular orbital theory and Hartree-Fock Theory
Describe and understand ab initio correlation methods
Describe and understand density functional theory
Understand and optimize the use of basis functions
Understand and explore the calculation of molecular structures and properties, e.g. spectroscopic and reaction-type molecular properties
Evaluate the expected accuracy of methods and approximations applied to a given electronic problem
Design best possible calculation type and system choice for a problem of interest
Hands-on implementation of various types of calculations
Content:
1. Review of mathematical concepts: Linear algebra, matrices, vectors, eigenvalue problem, wave functions, Operators, Dirac notation, electron integrals, elements of second quantization
2. Hartree-Fock Theory, Basis functions
3. Density Functional Theory (DFT): Principles, Approaches and Methods
4. Configuration Interaction (CI)
5. Multi-reference/Multi-configurational methods
6. (Møller-Plesset) Perturbation theory
7. Coupled-Cluster (CC) Theory
8. Multiscale/multilevel methods, e.g. QM/MM and QM/QM
9. Comparison of methods and requirements in relation to different types of problems: e.g., Geometry Optimizations, Binding Strengths, Solvent Effects, Transition States, Entropy and Gibb's Free Energy Calculations
10. How to compute molecular properties other than the energy
11. Excited states and spectroscopic calculations using different methods: Advantages and disadvantages
12. Hands-on implementation and application of different methods
